lessons.title: Christian Coaching Foundation
lessons.subtitle: Integrating faith and professional coaching to transform lives

sections.content: Hey {name}! Welcome to your Christian Coaching Certification journey. You have a calling on your life, and this training is going to equip you to answer it with confidence and skill. There are millions of believers who are struggling, searching for guidance, and longing for someone who understands their faith AND knows how to help them move forward. That someone is you.
What Is Christian Coaching and Why Does It Matter?

Christian coaching is a professional coaching practice that integrates biblical principles, prayer, and faith-based frameworks with proven coaching methodologies. It is not counseling, therapy, or pastoral care. It is forward-focused, action-oriented coaching that helps believers close the gap between where they are and where God is calling them to be. Whether that is in their relationships, career, health, purpose, or personal growth.

Christian coaching fills a unique space. Secular coaches do not integrate faith. Pastors are not trained in coaching methodology. Therapists focus on the past, not the future. Christian coaching brings all three worlds together: faith, professional skill, and forward movement.
The Gap in the Church

Here is a hard truth: most churches are not equipped to provide ongoing personal development support. Pastors are overworked, counseling waitlists are months long, and small groups can only go so deep. Meanwhile, believers are dealing with burnout, identity crises, career transitions, marriage struggles, and a deep sense that they are not living up to their God-given potential. They love Jesus but they are stuck. And they do not know who to call.

Research shows that 65 percent of churchgoing adults say they would seek coaching from a faith-based professional if it were available. The demand exists. The supply does not. That is your opportunity.
Scope of Practice

As an ASI-certified Christian Coach, you operate within a clear professional scope. You coach clients toward goals using biblical principles and proven frameworks. You help them identify purpose, overcome obstacles, build action plans, and develop accountability structures. You incorporate prayer, Scripture, and spiritual disciplines as tools. You do not provide therapy for mental health disorders, replace pastoral counseling for spiritual crises, or give professional financial or legal advice.

Scope of Practice: The professional boundaries within which a certified Christian coach operates. You coach forward, integrating faith with action. You refer to licensed counselors for clinical mental health needs, to pastors for deep theological or spiritual crises, and to professionals for legal or financial matters. Working within scope honors God and protects your practice.
The 5 Root Causes of Stagnation in Believers

When Christian clients come to you feeling stuck, unfulfilled, or directionless, the issue can almost always be traced to one or more of these five root causes. Understanding these patterns will make you an exceptionally effective Christian coach.
The 5 root causes you will address as a Christian Coach:
items: Identity Confusion: Not knowing who they are in Christ versus who the world says they should be. Many believers intellectually know their identity but have never internalized it. They live from performance and people-pleasing instead of from their God-given identity.

Fear-Based Living: Living in fear of failure, rejection, judgment, or the unknown instead of walking in faith. This keeps believers playing small, avoiding risk, and missing the assignments God has for them.

Unprocessed Pain Disguised as Faith: Burying hurt, anger, or disappointment under 'Christian' language. Saying 'I am blessed' while dying inside. This is the Christian version of spiritual bypassing, and it keeps people stuck in cycles they cannot name.

Lack of Vision and Direction: Having a general sense that God has more for them but no clarity on what that looks like practically. Without a clear vision and actionable plan, believers drift through years of unfulfilled potential.

Broken Accountability: No consistent structure for follow-through. Good intentions without accountability leads to repeated cycles of starting strong and fading out. This is not a character flaw. It is a systems problem that coaching solves.

sections.content: Sarah's Story

I was a faithful church member for 25 years but I was miserable. I knew God had more for me but I could not figure out what it was. My pastor was wonderful but he did not have time for ongoing coaching. My therapist helped with my anxiety but could not help me find my purpose. Then I found a Christian coach. In 90 days, she helped me identify my gifts, create a clear vision, and take action. I quit a job I hated and started a ministry that has impacted hundreds of women. I just needed someone who understood my faith AND could coach me forward. - Sarah D., now a Certified Christian Coach
Why This Niche Is Exploding
The Christian coaching market opportunity:
items: There are over 170 million Christians in the United States alone
The life coaching industry is worth over $2.85 billion and growing 5.4 percent annually
65 percent of churchgoing adults would seek faith-based coaching if available
Christian women in particular are seeking personal development that honors their values
Churches are increasingly partnering with certified Christian coaches for congregational support

questions.question: What makes Christian coaching different from pastoral counseling?
options: Christian coaching is forward-focused and action-oriented, not crisis or theology-focused
questions.explanation: Christian coaching is forward-focused and action-oriented. It helps believers move from where they are to where God is calling them. Pastoral counseling typically addresses spiritual crises, theological questions, and church-related concerns. They complement each other but serve different purposes.

questions.question: Which root cause describes believers who bury pain under 'Christian' language?
questions.explanation: Unprocessed Pain Disguised as Faith is the Christian version of spiritual bypassing. Believers say 'I am blessed' while suffering internally. This pattern keeps them stuck because the real pain is never acknowledged or addressed. A skilled Christian coach creates a safe space for honest processing.

sections.content: What Is Coming Next
In the next lesson, you will learn the G.R.A.C.E. Method, the proprietary framework that gives you a systematic, faith-integrated process for coaching every client toward breakthrough and purpose.

keyTakeaways: Christian coaching integrates faith, professional coaching skill, and forward movement in a way no other role does
65 percent of churchgoing adults would seek faith-based coaching if it were available
Five root causes drive stagnation in believers: identity confusion, fear-based living, unprocessed pain, lack of vision, and broken accountability
Christian coaches work within scope: coach forward with faith, refer out for therapy, deep theological crises, and professional advice
The Christian coaching market is massive with over 170 million US believers and growing demand

lessons.title: The G.R.A.C.E. Method™
lessons.subtitle: Your faith-integrated framework for coaching transformation

sections.content: Welcome back, {name}! Now that you understand the foundation of Christian coaching and the five root causes of stagnation, it is time to learn the G.R.A.C.E. Method. This framework gives you a professional, Spirit-led process for guiding every client from stuck to purpose-driven.
Why You Need a Framework

Having a heart for people is essential. But heart alone does not produce consistent results. Many gifted believers try to coach informally and end up in long, unfocused conversations that feel good but change nothing. The G.R.A.C.E. Method gives you the structure to steward your calling professionally while leaving room for the Holy Spirit to move.

steps.title: Discover
steps.description: Conduct a comprehensive faith-integrated intake. Explore the client's current life situation, faith journey, core struggles, dreams, gifts, values, and what they believe God is calling them toward. Open with prayer and create a space of trust where they can be fully honest without performing spirituality.

steps.title: Evaluate
steps.description: Analyze the intake against the 5 root causes of stagnation. Identify which patterns are keeping them stuck. Is it identity confusion? Fear-based decision making? Unprocessed pain hiding behind faith language? Most clients have 2-3 root causes interacting, and naming them brings immediate clarity.

steps.title: Pinpoint
steps.description: Prioritize the coaching focus. Determine which root cause is creating the most immediate stagnation and address it first. For many clients, identity work comes first because everything else flows from knowing who they are in Christ. For others, processing hidden pain must happen before forward movement is possible.

steps.title: Transform
steps.description: Implement the coaching plan using faith-integrated tools: identity declarations rooted in Scripture, vision-casting exercises, goal-setting with accountability, fear-to-faith reframing, forgiveness processes, and practical action steps. Each session combines coaching methodology with prayer and biblical application.

steps.title: Heal
steps.description: Build sustainable growth habits and spiritual disciplines that keep the client moving forward after coaching ends. This includes daily devotional practices, accountability partnerships, vision review routines, and triggers awareness so they recognize and respond to old patterns before falling back into them.

sections.content: D - Discover: The Faith-Integrated Intake

Open every coaching relationship with prayer and honest discovery. Ask about their faith journey, not just their church attendance. Ask what they believe God is calling them to. Ask where they feel stuck. Ask what they are afraid of. Ask what they are pretending is fine that is actually not. Many believers have never been asked these questions in a safe, non-judgmental space.

Create space for radical honesty. Many Christians are conditioned to perform spirituality, saying 'I am blessed' when they are actually struggling. Your intake should gently invite them to take off the mask. That is where real coaching begins.
E - Evaluate: Identifying the Root Pattern

With your intake complete, evaluate which root causes are active. A client who knows her gifts but never takes action is likely operating from fear. Someone who is successful by worldly standards but feels empty may have identity confusion, living from performance rather than God-given purpose. A woman who serves everyone but herself and feels resentful likely needs boundary work rooted in healthy self-stewardship.
P - Pinpoint: Setting the Coaching Focus

Choose the starting point wisely. Identity work is almost always foundational. When a client truly understands who she is in Christ, not intellectually but experientially, fear decreases, vision clarifies, and action becomes natural. For clients carrying unprocessed pain, you may need to facilitate honest acknowledgment and forgiveness before any forward-focused coaching can take root.
T - Transform: Faith-Integrated Coaching Tools
Core coaching tools you will use with clients:
items: Identity declarations: Personalized Scripture-based statements that replace lies with truth about who they are in Christ
Vision-casting exercises: Guided processes to clarify what God is calling them toward in specific areas of life
Fear-to-faith reframing: Identifying fear-based thoughts and replacing them with faith-based responses
Goal-setting with accountability: SMART goals combined with prayer, check-ins, and celebration milestones
Forgiveness processes: Guided steps for releasing bitterness and resentment that block forward movement
Action planning: Breaking big God-given vision into practical weekly steps

before.title: Before G.R.A.C.E. Method
items: Long conversations that feel good but produce no change
Giving advice instead of coaching toward discovery
No structure for tracking progress or milestones
Clients keep coming back with the same issues
Unsure how to integrate faith without being preachy

after.title: After G.R.A.C.E. Method
items: Focused sessions that produce measurable forward movement
Powerful questions that help clients discover God's answers for themselves
Clear progress tracking with accountability milestones
Clients break through patterns and step into purpose
Natural faith integration that honors the Spirit and respects the client

sections.content: H - Heal: Building Lasting Transformation

The Heal phase ensures that the breakthroughs your clients experience in coaching become permanent lifestyle changes. Help them establish morning devotional routines, create accountability partnerships outside of coaching, develop a personal vision statement they review weekly, and build awareness of the old patterns that used to keep them stuck. Your goal is to work yourself out of a job by empowering them to sustain their own growth.

Real-world application: A 48-year-old woman comes to you feeling called to start a women's ministry but paralyzed by fear and self-doubt. Using G.R.A.C.E. Method™, you Ground she has been sensing this call for 5 years but never acted on it. You Reveal and identify fear-based living and identity confusion as root causes, she does not believe she is 'qualified enough.' You Align identity as the starting point: she needs to know who she is in Christ before she can step out. You Cultivate over 90 days with identity declarations, vision-casting, fear-to-faith reframing, and practical action steps. You Equip by helping her build a daily devotional routine centered on her calling. Result: she launches her women's ministry and has 30 women in her first group within 60 days of completing coaching.

questions.question: Why is identity work often the first priority in Christian coaching?
options: It is the easiest topic to discuss
Everything flows from knowing who you are in Christ, including courage, vision, and action
Identity issues are the most common problem
Clients expect to talk about identity first
questions.explanation: When a client truly understands their identity in Christ, not just intellectually but experientially, fear decreases, vision clarifies, and action becomes natural. Identity is the foundation from which all other coaching breakthroughs flow.

questions.question: What does the 'E' in G.R.A.C.E. Method™ stand for in the Christian coaching framework?
questions.explanation: E stands for Evaluate. This is where you analyze the client's intake data against the 5 root causes of stagnation to identify which patterns are keeping them stuck. Accurate evaluation leads to targeted coaching that produces real results.

sections.content: What Is Coming Next

In the final lesson, you will learn exactly how to get your first Christian coaching clients, set your pricing, and build a practice that generates $5,000 or more per month while fulfilling the calling God has placed on your life.

keyTakeaways: The G.R.A.C.E. Method gives your calling a professional structure that produces consistent breakthroughs
Ground creates radical honesty through prayer and safe space, Reveal identifies root patterns, Align sets the coaching focus
Transform uses faith-integrated tools: identity declarations, vision-casting, fear-to-faith reframing, and action planning
Identity work is almost always foundational because everything else flows from knowing who you are in Christ
Heal builds sustainable spiritual disciplines so clients maintain growth independently

lessons.title: How To Get Your First Clients
lessons.subtitle: Build a thriving Christian coaching practice from day one

sections.content: Congratulations, {name}! You now have the knowledge AND the G.R.A.C.E. Method framework to coach believers toward purpose and breakthrough. In this final lesson, you will learn the exact strategy to get your first paying clients and build a Christian coaching practice that honors God, serves others, and provides abundantly for you and your family.
The Warm Market Strategy

Your first clients are already in your life. They are in your church, your small group, your workplace, and your social circles. Think about the women who have asked for your advice, who have shared their struggles with you over coffee, who have told you they feel stuck or called to something more. They already trust you. Now you have the professional training to serve them at the highest level.
Your warm market includes:
items: Women in your church or small group who are going through transitions
Friends who talk about feeling stuck, unfulfilled, or uncertain about their purpose
Colleagues who are believers dealing with career decisions or burnout
Members of Christian women's groups on social media
Mothers navigating empty nest, identity shifts, or new seasons of life
Anyone who has ever said 'I know God has more for me but I do not know what it is'

sections.content: Charging for Christian coaching is not unbiblical. The worker is worthy of her wages. Your training, time, and expertise have value. When you charge, you attract committed clients who do the work. When you coach for free, people do not value it enough to change.
The Conversation Framework

When a fellow believer shares that she is stuck or searching, say: 'I just completed a professional certification in Christian coaching. I am building my practice and taking on a few clients. Would you be open to a free 15-minute call so I can learn more about what you are going through and see if coaching might help?' This is ministry and profession working together.
Pricing Your Services

Believers invest in conferences, books, retreats, and programs that offer general inspiration. Your coaching offers personalized transformation. That is worth significantly more. Price your services to reflect the life-changing value you deliver.
Recommended pricing structure:
items: Discovery call: Free (15 minutes to assess fit and pray together)
Single coaching session: $100 to $175 per session
90-day purpose and breakthrough package: $1,500 to $2,500 (10-12 sessions plus resources)
Group coaching cohort (6-8 women): $397 to $797 per person
Monthly coaching maintenance: $175 to $350 per month

sections.content: Always offer 90-day packages over single sessions. Lasting transformation does not happen in one conversation. A 90-day container gives clients the time, accountability, and structure to break through patterns that have held them back for years.
Your Income Potential

If you take on 3 clients per month on a 90-day package at $1,800 each, that is $5,400 per month. Launch a group coaching cohort with 8 women at $597 each and add another $4,776. Many Christian coaches reach $7,000 to $12,000 per month within their first year, doing work that feels like ministry and pays like a profession.

sections.content: The Value of Your ASI Certification

Your ASI certification from the AccrediPro Standards Institute distinguishes you as a professionally trained Christian coach. It tells potential clients and church leaders that you have completed rigorous training, that you operate within ethical boundaries, and that you integrate faith with evidence-based coaching methodology. This opens doors to church partnerships, conference invitations, and referral networks.

Churches are increasingly looking for certified Christian coaches to partner with for congregational development, women's ministry support, and leadership coaching. Your ASI credential makes you the professional they trust to work with their members.
Scope of Practice Reminder

As you launch your practice, stay within scope. You coach believers forward using faith-integrated frameworks. You help them find purpose, overcome fear, and take action. You refer to licensed counselors for depression, anxiety disorders, trauma processing, and other clinical needs. You refer to pastors for deep theological or spiritual crises. You refer to professionals for legal and financial advice. This is not a limitation. It is a mark of professionalism and wisdom.
Your 30-Day Launch Plan
Follow this plan to get your first clients within 30 days:
items: Week 1: List 20 women in your life of faith who are stuck, in transition, or searching for purpose. Reach out to 5 with your free 15-minute call offer.
Week 2: Conduct free discovery calls and offer your 90-day package to those who are ready for change.
Week 3: Share your coaching certification journey in your church community and on social media. Post about what Christian coaching is and who it serves.
Week 4: Follow up with all contacts. Ask your pastor about partnership opportunities. Ask for referrals from anyone who engaged. Book your first paying clients.

sections.content: I felt called to coach for years but I did not think I was qualified. This certification changed everything. My first client was a woman from my small group who had been praying about her purpose for 3 years but never taking action. After 90 days of coaching, she launched a non-profit that now serves over 200 families. She told me our coaching sessions were the most impactful thing she had experienced since coming to faith. That is when I knew: this is what I was made for. - Sarah D., Christian Coach

questions.question: Where will your first Christian coaching clients most likely come from?
options: Your church community and warm market
questions.explanation: Your church community and warm market are your strongest starting point. These are people who already know your character, share your faith, and trust you. Many of them are already seeking the kind of guidance you are now certified to provide.

questions.question: Why are 90-day coaching packages recommended over single sessions?
options: Real transformation requires sustained accountability, identity work, and action over time
Single sessions are too short to pray together
questions.explanation: Lasting breakthrough does not happen in one session. A 90-day package provides the time, accountability, and structure needed to address root causes, rebuild identity, overcome fear, and take sustained action toward God-given purpose.

sections.content: Your Next Step

You have completed all three lessons of your Christian Coaching Foundation training. Take the certification exam to earn your ASI-accredited credential and step into the calling God has placed on your life.

You have the knowledge, the framework, and the strategy. God did not give you this calling to keep it to yourself. Take the exam, get certified, and reach out to your first 5 warm market contacts this week. Your obedience will change lives.
